title: Mum trolled for 'hitting' baby – but she was doing it for powerful reason
text:

A mother has shared a moving video in which she shows the harsh realities of caring for a baby with cystic fibrosis . 
Sam Carrier, from Birmingham, posted footage on her Daisy Evans Journey Facebook page, which she started to raise awareness of the condition. 
Unfortunately, Sam was 'trolled' by some users, who clearly didn't understand what she was doing is absolutely necessary. Sam even received a death threat and was called a "child beater", BBC West Midlands reports. Not everyone is aware of the problems with cystic fibrosis (Photo: Daisy Evans Journey) 
Although some of the more worrying comments have been removed, some remain – and they only go to further exemplify the lack of understanding around cystic fibrosis. 
Sarah Louise questioned: "How can u do that 2 the baby". 
Thankfully, Sam mainly received huge support from others after her post. The mum wanted to underline how difficult it can be to keep a child with the illness safe, and hundreds of others sent their love and admiration. Most people praised Sam's post: 
Hundreds of others wanted to show their respect for Sam and baby Daisy. 
Sarah Meighan said: "Your doing a fantastic job mum. I have to do this also as my baby has cystic fibrosis too but only 2 times a day and she is doing great at 14 month old yes a lot of hospital trips but she in good hand of a mother/father at home, keep up the great work xx". 
And Kelly May wrote: "U people that wrote nasty comments, lay of this mother she is doin it for babys health.i have cystic fibrosis and if i thought any u spoke my mom like this id screw.read her comment u t*** sending hugs daisy warrior x". Funding page: Sam says she was frightened when she first found out about her daughter's condition (Photo: Daisy Evans Journey) 
Sam has also set up a funding page where she talks more about her daughter Daisy's condition, and the efforts she and her family go to in order to care for her. 
"On the 26th October I had a knock on my door from a nurse from Birmingham Children's Hospital," Sam said. 
"My heart sank when she said she was here about Daisy's heel prick test. Daisy tested positive for two strands of cystic fibrosis. One common and one rare. 
"My world fell apart. It was one of the worst days of my life." Beautiful baby Daisy (Photo: Daisy Evans Journey) Read More How these twelve lemons are helping women fight breast cancer 
Sam and her husband Rob want to raise money to help fund the Cystic Fibrosis Trust. They hope there might one day be a cure – currently, there isn't, though there are lots of things people can do to help ease the condition. 
In Sam's video, she was doing something called the 'active cycle of breathing techniques' (ACBT). 
According to the NHS website , which has lots of other information on cystic fibrosis, ACBT is "a technique that involves a sequence of relaxed breathing, followed by deep breathing exercises and then huffing". Read More
